items.title: PyPy support
items.body:
Any plan to support PyPy / PyPy3 ?

With PyPy I get this error:
`ImportError: unable to load extension module '[path removed]/pysendfile-2.0.1-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg-tmp/sendfile.so': [path removed]/pysendfile-2.0.1-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg-tmp/sendfile.so: undefined symbol: PyExc_OSError`

And with PyPy3 :
`ImportError: unable to load extension module '[path removed]/pysendfile-2.0.1-py3.2-linux-x86_64.egg/sendfile.pypy3-23.so': [path removed]/pysendfile-2.0.1-py3.2-linux-x86_64.egg/sendfile.pypy3-23.so: undefined symbol: PyModule_GetState`

I'm using PyPy portable installs from [here](https://github.com/squeaky-pl/portable-pypy).

items.title: README has incorrect example usage
items.body:
_From [jlen...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/113769459583768933722/) on April 22, 2013 17:37:23_

The README says

```
if err.errno == (errno.EAGAIN, errno.EBUSY):  # retry
    continue
```

err.errno will never be a tuple, so that will always be False.

**Attachment:** [pysendfile.patch](http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=18)

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=18_

items.title: Debian, Ubuntu and Redhat packaging
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 08, 2012 20:23:03_

pysendfile seems to be included in different major Linux distributions already. 
The packaged version is still 1.2.4 though (year 2009), which is not fully compatible with the current 2.0.0 version.
2.0.0 version was basically rewritten from scratch and includes numerous bug fixes and improvements which are listed here: http://pysendfile.googlecode.com/svn/tags/release-2.0.0/HISTORY As such, it would be recommended for Linux distros to upgrade and provide packages for the newer 2.0.0 version.

Altough I'm not directly involved in any of this, I'm opening this issue to keep track of the different package upgrades since I've already received a bunch of emails from different people and I'm rapidly loosing track of what's going on.

Ghe Rivero, Eoghan Glynn and Janoš Guljaš: if needed, feel free to coordinate everything from here.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=15_

items.title: Linux, automatically update file offset when offset arg == None
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on April 20, 2011 18:52:56_

On linux, if offset is passed as NULL, sendfile() is supposed to automatically updated by file offset.
We should support this in case the user passes offset == None.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=14_

items.title: Add SunOS support
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on April 17, 2011 22:24:31_

SunOS also supports sendfile() even though header and trailer are not supported.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=13_

items.title: Support headers and trailers also on Linux
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on April 16, 2011 16:56:59_

From man sendfile:

```
   If you plan to use sendfile() for  sending  files  to  a  TCP
   socket,  but  need  to  send some header data in front of the
   file contents, you will find it useful to employ the TCP_CORK
   option,  described in tcp(7), to minimize the number of pack‐
   ets and to tune performance.
```

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=12_

items.title: Add OSX support
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on April 08, 2011 22:57:59_

OSX support is currently not supported.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=11_

items.title: Just send file data less than 1KB
items.body:
_From [YL.Bo...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/113410371592898045921/) on February 23, 2011 12:12:46_

What steps will reproduce the problem? path = QUERY.get('path','')

```
fp = open(path, 'rb')
name = os.path.basename(path)
size = os.path.getsize(path)

sock = REQUEST_HANDLER.sock
sock.sendall("""HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nPragma: no-cache\r\nExpires: 0\r\nCache-Control: no-cache, no-store\r\nContent-Disposition: attachment; filename="%s"\r\nContent-Type: application/octet-stream\r\nContent-Length: %s\r\n\r\n""" % (name, str(size)))
offset = 0
nbytes = 4096
while 1:
    try:
        sent = sendfile.sendfile(sock.fileno(), fp.fileno(), offset, nbytes)
    except OSError, err:
        if err.errno in (errno.EAGAIN, errno.EBUSY):  # retry
            continue
        raise
    else:
        if sent == 0:
            break    # done
        offset += sent
fp.close() What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Just send file data less than 1KB. And this file is intact. When file size larger than 1KB, the download progress bar show "Downloading..." all the while, and the progress is 0 all the while. Can not download. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Source : svn checkout http://py-sendfile.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ py-sendfile-read-only
```

Version 2.0.0 - XXXX-XX-XX
Operating system: ubuntu64 2.6.32-24-server
HTTP Server: Karrigell-3.1.1
Python: 2.7.1

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=10_

items.title: Provide a benchmark script
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 08, 2011 20:28:52_

A simple benchmark script which compares send() and sendfile() performances (CPU usage and bytes transferred per second).

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=9_

items.title: Add SF_NODISKIO, SF_MNOWAIT and SF_SYNC constants on FreeBSD
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 07, 2011 19:22:01_

http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=sendfile&sektion=2

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=7_

items.title: Add support for keyword arguments
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 03, 2011 18:30:19_

This should be available on all those platforms accepting "headers", "trailers" and "flags" arguments so that sendfile() can be used as such:

sendfile.sendfile(sock, file, offset, 4096, headers="foo")
sendfile.sendfile(sock, file, offset, 4096, trailers="bar")

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=6_

items.title: Sendfile should return the right type depending on whether Python has large file support or not
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 03, 2011 14:28:43_

Something like this:
# if !defined(HAVE_LARGEFILE_SUPPORT)

```
    return Py_BuildValue("iL", sts, offset);
```
# else

```
    return Py_BuildValue("il", sts, offset);
```
# endif

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=5_

items.title: FreeBSD implementation is broken
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 03, 2011 14:16:04_

From freebsd man page:

> When using a socket marked for non-blocking I/O, sendfile() may send
> fewer bytes than requested.  In this case, the number of bytes 
> success-fully written is returned in *sbytes (if specified), and the 
> error EAGAIN is returned.

...and the similar note about EBUSY, later in the page.

Current code just raises such errors without checking if data has been sent.
Instead of raising exception it should return the number of bytes sent.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=4_

items.title: Add python 3 support
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 03, 2011 13:34:34_

The module currently supports Python 2.x only.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=3_

items.title: Write test suite
items.body:
_From [g.rodola](https://code.google.com/u/g.rodola/) on February 03, 2011 13:34:19_

Current test suite is very poor.
A consistent one should be written.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysendfile/issues/detail?id=2_
